tool.name: taxpasta
tool.command:
## Getting the NCBI taxonomy database ## In future could find the one that exists in Galaxy and give user option to instead use that cached one
curl -O -s ftp://ftp.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pub/taxonomy/taxdump.tar.gz && mkdir ./taxdump && tar -C ./taxdump -xzf taxdump.tar.gz && taxpasta $action -p $profiler -o ./output.tsv --taxonomy taxdump --add-name #for $file in $infile: '$file' #end for && mv ./output.tsv $output
## Outputs

param.name: infile
param.label: Choose taxonomic report(s) to standardise
param.help: Select one or many reports, but only from the same profiling tool

param.name: profiler
param.label: What profiling tool created this report?

param.name: action
param.label: What should taxpasta do?
param.help: Only run merge if inputs are from the same profiler

tool.help:
.. class:: infomark
**What it does**
* Taxpasta standardises the taxonomic profiles produced from other tools. * It reformats these outputs into a table of NCBI taxonomy identifiers and their integer counts. * Then, it converts these identifiers to taxon names. * It can also merge outputs across samples, from the same profiling tool.
**Input**
* One or many outputs from a particular profiling tool, such as kraken2 or diamond. * Check that this report is in the correct format for taxpasta: for detail, see https://taxpasta.readthedocs.io/en/latest/supported_profilers/. * For example, for kraken2, taxpasta expects the kraken-report output file with 6 or 8 columns. * For example, for diamond, taxpasta expects a tabular file with 3 columns.
**Output**
* A reformatted report, either for the single input, or for multiple inputs, as long as they are from the same profiling tool. * The report is in tabular format.
For more information see: https://taxpasta.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
